emerging_technologies.name: AI-Driven Code Autonomy
emerging_technologies.description: AI systems capable of autonomously writing, debugging, and optimizing code, reducing human intervention in software development.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: This technology will disrupt traditional software engineering roles, increase software development speed, and potentially lead to a software glut. Ethical considerations include job displacement and the need for AI governance in code creation.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: High adoption due to the promise of efficiency and cost savings in software development. Barriers include resistance from developers, concerns over AI reliability, and potential legal issues regarding code ownership.

emerging_technologies.name: Autonomous Urban Infrastructure Management
emerging_technologies.description: A network of AI-managed systems for optimizing urban infrastructure, including traffic flow, waste management, and public utilities.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Enhances urban living through reduced congestion, efficient resource use, and improved quality of life. Ethical issues include privacy concerns, potential for AI bias in decision-making, and the displacement of human labor in public services.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Adoption driven by the need for smart cities, environmental sustainability, and economic efficiency. Challenges include high initial costs, cybersecurity, and public trust in AI decision-making.

emerging_technologies.name: Neuralink Cognitive Enhancement
emerging_technologies.description: Implantable brain-computer interfaces for cognitive enhancement, memory storage, and direct communication.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Potential for significant human enhancement, leading to ethical debates about fairness, privacy, and the definition of humanity. Regulatory frameworks will be necessary to manage the implications of cognitive upgrades.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Adoption will depend on safety, efficacy, and ethical acceptance. Barriers include regulatory approval, public perception, and the technical challenge of brain-computer integration.

mainstream_technologies.name: AI-Driven Code Autonomy
mainstream_technologies.description: AI systems that autonomously handle software development tasks.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Becoming standard in software development, with widespread use in tech companies and educational institutions. Adoption is spurred by productivity gains but faces resistance due to job displacement fears.

epoch_themes.description: AI becomes deeply integrated into personal and professional activities, enhancing productivity and decision-making.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: AI integration reshapes job markets, education, and personal interaction, raising ethical questions about autonomy, privacy, and the future of work.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Global push towards AI ethics, AI-driven economic models, and the development of AI governance frameworks.

epoch_themes.description: Cities leverage AI and autonomous systems to become more sustainable and efficient.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Improves urban living standards, reduces environmental impact, and potentially alters urban-rural dynamics.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Increased focus on smart city initiatives, sustainability goals, and the integration of technology in urban planning.
